AI Is Causing a Grim New Twist on the Dunning-Kruger Effect, Research FindsFrank Landymore11/7/2025

New research shows how AI tools is making a Dunning-Kruger specimen out of everyone that uses them, no matter how smart.

Read

My work at Futurism has been cited by publications including CBS News, the Los Angeles Times, Vice, Gizmodo, Engadget, the Verge, and Vanity Fair. \r\n\r\nI grew up in locales ranging from India to China, and now live in the exotic suburbs of Virginia. Allegedly, I’m working on a debut novel, currently untitled.","url":"https://futurism.com/authors/flandymore","image":"https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/avatar_user_156407_1741024615.jpg?quality=85","sameAs":["https://bsky.app/profile/f-w-l.bsky.social"]}],"headline":"AI Is Causing a Grim New Twist on the Dunning-Kruger Effect, Research Finds","datePublished":"2025-10-30T09:06:43-04:00","mainEntityOfPage":{"@id":"https://futurism.com/artificial-intelligence/ai-dunning-kruger-effect"},"wordCount":633,"commentCount":0,"publisher":{"@id":"https://futurism.com/#organization"},"image":{"@id":"https://futurism.com/artificial-intelligence/ai-dunning-kruger-effect#primaryimage"},"thumbnailUrl":"https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/ai-dunning-kruger-effect.jpg?quality=85","articleSection":["Artificial Intelligence","Brain","Health & Medicine","Mental Health"],"inLanguage":"en-US","potentialAction":[{"@type":"CommentAction","name":"Comment","target":["https://futurism.com/artificial-intelligence/ai-dunning-kruger-effect#respond"]}],"dateModified":"2025-10-30T09:06:43-04:00","ArticleBody":"People who are the worst at doing something also tend to severely overestimate how good they are at doing it, while those who are actually skilled tend to not realize their true talent.\n\n\n\nThis galling cognitive bias is called the Dunning-Kruger effect, as you're probably familiar — and would you believe it if we told you that AI appears to make it even worse? \n\n\n\nCase in point, a new study published in the journal Computers in Human Behavior — and titled, memorably, \"AI Makes You smarter But None the Wiser\") — showed that everyone was bad at estimating their own performance after being asked to complete a series of tasks using ChatGPT. And strikingly, it was the participants who were \"AI literate\" who were the worst offenders.\n\n\n\n\"When it comes to AI, the [Dunning-Kruger effect] vanishes,\" study senior author Robin Welsch, a professor at Aalto University, said in a statement about the work. \"In fact, what's really surprising is that higher AI literacy brings more overconfidence.\"\n\n\n\n\"We would expect people who are AI literate to not only be a bit better at interacting with AI systems, but also at judging their performance with those systems,\" Welsch added, \"but this was not the case.\"\n\n\n\nIt's an interesting detail that helps build on our still burgeoning understanding of all the ways that our AI habits are probably bad for our brains, from being linked with memory loss to atrophying our critical thinking skills. Perhaps it's also a testament to the ego of the AI power user.\n\n\n\nNotably, the findings comes amid heated debate around the dangerous \"sycophancy\" of AI models. Chatbots designed to both be helpful and engaging constantly ply users with flattery and go along with their demands. It's an addictive combination that makes you feel smart or vindicated. And this sycophancy is thought to be one of the main driving factors behind widespread cases of what psychiatrists are calling \"AI psychosis,\" in which users suffer breaks with reality and spirals into delusional thinking after becoming obsessed with talking with a chatbot.\n\n\n\nIn the study, the researchers asked half of 500 participants to use ChatGPT to help solve 20 logical reasoning problems from the Law School Admission Test, and the other half to solve them without AI. Afterwards, each participant was asked to evaluate their own performance, with the promise of extra compensation if they did so accurately. They were also administered a questionnaire designed to gauge their AI literacy.\n\n\n\nThe researchers found that the group that used ChatGPT substantially improved their scores compared to the group that didn't. But they also vastly overestimated their performance — and the effect was especially pronounced among the AI savvy, \"suggesting that those with more technical knowledge of AI were more confident but less precise in judging their own performance,\" the authors wrote.\n\n\n\nWhen they examined how the participants used the chatbot, the team also discovered that the majority of them rarely asked ChatGPT more than one question per problem — with no further probing or double checking. According to Welsch, this is an example of what psychiatrists call cognitive offloading, a well documented trend in AI in which users outsource all their thinking to an AI tool.\n\n\n\n\"We looked at whether they truly reflected with the AI system and found that people just thought the AI would solve things for them,\" Welsch said. \"Usually there was just one single interaction to get the results, which means that users blindly trusted the system.\"\n\n\n\nYou've got to hand it to AI: it's democratizing the Dunning-Kruger effect. What other tech can claim to do that?\n\n\n\nMore on AI: Character.AI, Accused of Driving Teens to Suicide, Says It Will Ban Minors From Using Its Chatbots"},{"@type":"WebPage","@id":"https://futurism.com/artificial-intelligence/ai-dunning-kruger-effect","url":"https://futurism.com/artificial-intelligence/ai-dunning-kruger-effect","name":"AI Is Causing a Grim New Twist on the Dunning-Kruger Effect, Research Finds","isPartOf":{"@id":"https://futurism.com/#website"},"primaryImageOfPage":{"@id":"https://futurism.com/artificial-intelligence/ai-dunning-kruger-effect#primaryimage"},"image":{"@id":"https://futurism.com/artificial-intelligence/ai-dunning-kruger-effect#primaryimage"},"thumbnailUrl":"https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/ai-dunning-kruger-effect.jpg?quality=85","datePublished":"2025-10-30T09:06:43-04:00","description":"New research shows how AI tools is making a Dunning-Kruger specimen out of everyone that uses them, no matter how smart.","breadcrumb":{"@id":"https://futurism.com/artificial-intelligence/ai-dunning-kruger-effect#breadcrumb"},"inLanguage":"en-US","potentialAction":[{"@type":"ReadAction","target":["https://futurism.com/artificial-intelligence/ai-dunning-kruger-effect"]}],"dateModified":"2025-10-30T09:06:43-04:00"},{"@type":"ImageObject","inLanguage":"en-US","@id":"https://futurism.com/artificial-intelligence/ai-dunning-kruger-effect#primaryimage","url":"https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/ai-dunning-kruger-effect.jpg?quality=85","contentUrl":"https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/ai-dunning-kruger-effect.jpg?quality=85","width":2048,"height":1365,"caption":"Illustration by Tag Hartman-Simkins / Futurism. .MembershipTable > ul {
	align-items: stretch;
	display: grid;
	grid-gap: 30px;
	grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr;
	list-style: none;
	margin: 0 auto;
	padding: 0 0 0 0;
}

.MembershipTable .Membership {
	background-color: #FFF;
	border-radius: 10px;
	margin-top: 30px;
	list-style: none;
}

.MembershipTable .Membership.Membership-isBest {
	box-shadow: 0px 4px 9px 0px rgba(0, 0, 0, .4);
	margin-top: 0;
}

.MembershipTable .Membership .Membership-inner {
	align-items: flex-start;
	display: flex;
	flex-direction: column;
	height: 100%;
	padding: 49px 28px 24px;
}

.MembershipTable .Membership.Membership-isBest .Membership-inner {
	height: calc(100% - 30px);
}

.Membership-inner > * {
	width: 100%;
}

.Membership-inner ul,
.Membership-inner ol {
	margin-left: 0;
	padding-left: 20px;
}

.Membership-inner ul li {
	list-style: disc;
}

.Membership-inner ol li {
	list-style: decimal;
}

.Membership-inner ul li,
.Membership-inner ol li {
	padding-bottom: 1em;
}

.Membership-bestLable {
	background-color: #61A0F8;
	border-radius: 10px 10px 0 0;
	color: #FFF;
	display: block;
	font-size: 14px;
	font-weight: 400;
	height: 30px;
	line-height: 30px;
	padding: 0 0;
	text-align: center;
	width: 100%;
}

.Membership-heading {
	border-bottom: 1px solid #000;
	padding: 0 0 12px;
}

.Membership-heading .title {
	display: block;
	font-size: 21px;
	font-weight: 600;
	line-height: 1em;
	margin: 0 0 7px;
}

.MembershipTable .Membership-inner .Membership-heading p {
	font-size: 14px;
	font-weight: 200;
	line-height: 1em;
	margin: 0 0 10px;
	font-family: neue-haas-grotesk-display-thin, sans-serif;
}

.MembershipTable .Membership-content,
.MembershipTable .Membership-highlighted,
.MembershipTable .MembershipDetail-accordion {
	flex-grow: 1;
	font-size: 14px;
	font-weight: 450;
	line-height: 1.1em;
	padding: 24px 0;
}

.MembershipTable .Membership-highlighted {
	padding: 25px 0;
}

.MembershipTable .Membership-inner .Membership-content *,
.MembershipTable .Membership-inner .Membership-highlighted *,
.MembershipTable .Membership-inner .MembershipDetail-accordion * {
	line-height: 1.1em;
}

.MembershipTable .Membership-inner .Membership-highlighted p,
.MembershipTable .Membership-inner .MembershipDetail-accordion p,
.MembershipTable .Membership-inner .Membership-highlighted li,
.MembershipTable .Membership-inner .MembershipDetail-accordion li {
	padding-bottom: 1em;
	margin-block-start: 0;
	margin-block-end: 0;
}

.MembershipTable .Membership-inner .Membership-highlighted p:last-child,
.MembershipTable .Membership-inner .MembershipDetail-accordion p:last-child,
.MembershipTable .Membership-inner .Membership-highlighted li:last-child,
.MembershipTable .Membership-inner .MembershipDetail-accordion li:last-child {
	padding-bottom: 0;
}

.MembershipTable a.Membership-button {
	display: inline-block;
	font-weight: 500;
	letter-spacing: 0.1em;
	line-height: 1em;
	margin-bottom: 8px;
	padding: 12px 18px;
}

body:not(.home) #page .page-content .entry-content .MembershipTable a.Membership-button {
	text-decoration-line: none;
}

.MembershipTable .Membership-example {
	color: #61A0F8;
	display: block;
	font-size: 11px;
	font-weight: 500;
	text-decoration-line: underline;
}

.MembershipTable .Membership-highlighted {
	display: none;
}

.MembershipTable .MembershipDetail-accordion {
	display: block;
	height: 0px;
	overflow: hidden;
	transition: all linear .2s;
	padding: 0 0;
}

.Membership .MembershipDetail-button,
.Membership .MembershipDetail-button:hover {
	color: #000;
	font-size: 14px;
	font-weight: 700;
	text-decoration: underline;
}

.Membership .MembershipDetail-button .less,
.Membership .MembershipDetail-button .more {
	text-decoration: underline;
}

.Membership-details {
	display: none;
	padding: 16px 0 0 0;
}

.Membership-details .less,
.Membership-details.open .more {
	text-decoration: underline;
	display: none;
}

.MembershipDetail-button:after {
	border: solid #000;
	border-width: 0 2px 2px 0;
	content: "";
	display: inline-block;
	height: 6px;
	margin: 0 0 0 5px;
	position: relative;
	top: -2px;
	transform: rotate(45deg);
	width: 6px;
	transition: all linear .3s;
}

.Membership-details.open .MembershipDetail-button:after {
	transform: rotate(225deg);
	top: 0;
}

.Membership-details.open .less {
	display: inline-block;
}

.Membership-details.open .MembershipDetail-accordion {
	height: 100%;
	padding: 24px 0 0;
}

@media (max-width: 1024px) {
	.Membership-inner {
		padding: 49px 20px 16px;
	}
}

@media (max-width: 800px) {
	.MembershipTable > ul {
		grid-template-columns: 1fr;
	}

	.Membership {
		order: 1;
	}

	.MembershipTable .Membership.Membership-isBest {
		order: 0;
		box-shadow: none;
	}

	.Membership .Membership-content {
		display: none;
	}

	.Membership .Membership-details,
	.Membership .Membership-highlighted {
		display: block;
	}
}

@media (max-width: 664px) {
	.Membership-heading {
		padding: 0 0 15px;
	}

	.MembershipTable .Membership .Membership-inner {
		padding: 50px 30px 25px;
	}

	.MembershipTable .Membership-button {
		font-weight: 500;
		font-size: 10px;
		line-height: 1em;
		padding: 16px 23px;
	}
}

</style>
<style id='acf-newsletter-review-style-inline-css'>
.NewsletterReviews-block {
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: center;
}

.NewsletterReviews-block .NewsletterReviews-title {
  border-bottom: 1px solid #000;
  display: block;
  font-size: 12px;
  font-weight: 700;
  letter-spacing: 0.01em;
  line-height: 1em;
  padding: 0 5px 10px;
  margin: 0 0 50px;
  text-align: center;
  text-transform: uppercase;
}

.NewsletterReviews-wrapper {
  min-height: 300px;
  overflow: hidden;
  width: 100%;
  transition: height ease .3s;
}

.NewsletterReviews-list {
  align-items: start;
  display: flex;
  transform: translateX(0%);
  transition: all ease .2s;
}

body.page .entry-content .NewsletterReviews-block ul.NewsletterReviews-indicators,
body.page .entry-content .NewsletterReviews-block ul.NewsletterReviews-list {
  margin: 0;
  padding: 0;
}

body.page .entry-content .NewsletterReviews-block .NewsletterReviews-indicators li,
body.page .entry-content .NewsletterReviews-block .NewsletterReviews-list li {
  list-style: none;
}

.NewsletterReview {
  align-items: center;
  display: flex;
  justify-content: center;
  margin-right: 30px;
  min-height: 300px;
  min-width: 100%;
  padding: 0;
}

.NewsletterReview .NewsletterReview-content {
  align-items: center;
  background: #fff;
  border-radius: 10px;
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  justify-items: center;
  margin-top: 40px;
  max-width: 540px;
  min-height: 195px;
  padding: 60px 30px 40px;
  position: relative;
  width: 100%;
}

.NewsletterReview .NewsletterReview-content.noPicture {
  margin-top: 0px;
}

.NewsletterReview .NewsletterReview-figure {
  border-radius: 100%;
  height: 80px;
  left: calc(50% - 40px);
  overflow: hidden;
  position: absolute;
  top: -40px;
  width: 80px;
}

.NewsletterReview .NewsletterReview-figure img {
  aspect-ratio: 1 / 1;
  height: 100%;
  width: 100%;
  object-fit: cover;
  object-position: top center;
}

.NewsletterReview .NewsletterReview-testimonial {
  padding-bottom: 15px;
}

.NewsletterReview .NewsletterReview-testimonial,
.NewsletterReview .NewsletterReview-testimonial * {
  font-size: 35px;
  font-weight: 450;
  letter-spacing: -0.01em;
  line-height: 1em;
}

.NewsletterReview .NewsletterReview-signature {
  font-size: 16px;
  font-weight: 450;
  letter-spacing: -0.01em;
  line-height: 1em;
}

.NewsletterReview .NewsletterReview-signature > p:first-child,
.NewsletterReview .NewsletterReview-testimonial > p:first-child {
  margin-top: 0;
}

.NewsletterReview .NewsletterReview-signature > p:last-child,
.NewsletterReview .NewsletterReview-testimonial > p:last-child {
  margin-bottom: 0;
}

body.page .entry-content .NewsletterReviews-block ul.NewsletterReviews-indicators {
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: row;
  gap: 10px;
  position: relative;
  padding-top: 50px;
}

.NewsletterReviews-indicators li {
  background-color: transparent;
  border: 1px solid #000;
  border-radius: 10px;
  cursor: pointer;
  display: block;
  height: 10px;
  width: 10px;
}

.NewsletterReviews-indicators li.current {
  background-color: #000;
  content: '';
  cursor: inherit;
  left: 0;
  position: absolute;
  transition: left ease .2s;
}

.NewsletterReviews-indicators li.current {
  background-color: #000;
}

@media (max-width: 664px) {
  .NewsletterReview .NewsletterReview-content {
    padding: 65px 22px 40px;
  }

  .NewsletterReview .NewsletterReview-testimonial {
    font-size: 30px;
  }
}

</style>
<style id='recurrent-newsletter-email-style-inline-css'>
.newsletter-signup-form-wrapper {
	position: relative;
}

.newsletter-signup-success {
	display: none;

	width: 100%;

.newsletter-image-wrapper {

	position: relative;
}

.newsletter-signup-form-wrapper {

.newsletter-signup-success {
	display: none;

<style id='recurrent-rss-3x3-block-style-inline-css'>
.domino-rss-3x3-block {
	margin-bottom: 2.5rem;
}

<style id='recurrent-top-stories-style-inline-css'>
.recurrent-top-story-block .content-box-title {
	font-weight: 700;
	margin-bottom: 1.25rem;
	text-align: center;
}

.recurrent-top-stories-container {
	display: flex;
	overflow-x: auto;
	grid-template-columns: repeat(3, minmax(0, 1fr));
	gap: 1.5rem;
	margin-bottom: 1rem;
	padding: 0 !important;
}

.recurrent-top-stories-container > li {
	position: relative;
	list-style: none;
	min-width: 280px;
	width: 280px;

	.card-post {
		height: 100%;

		.post-content {
			height: 100%;
    		display: flex;
    		flex-direction: column;

			.card-post-byline {
				margin-top: auto;

				.article-byline .item-wrapper {
					margin-right: 0;
				}
			}
		}
	}
}

.recurrent-top-stories-container > li:not(:last-child)::after {
	content: '';
	position: absolute;
	background-color: #d1d5db;
	right: -0.75rem;
	top: 0;
	bottom: auto;
	left: auto;
	height: 100%;
	width: 1px;
}

.recurrent-top-story-block .post-tax-badges .sponsored-badge {
	margin: 0 auto;
}

@media (min-width: 1024px) {
	.recurrent-top-stories-container {
		display: grid;
		gap: 1.75rem;
	}

	.recurrent-top-stories-container > li {
		min-width: 0;
		width: auto;
	}

	.recurrent-top-stories-container > li:not(:last-child)::after {
		right: -0.875rem;
	}

	.recurrent-top-story-block .content-box-title {
		margin-bottom: 2rem;
	}
}

</style>

			<h1 class="article-title">AI Is Causing a Grim New Twist on the Dunning-Kruger Effect, Research Finds</h1>
			<div class="article-dek">AI users are lacking in self-awareness.</div>

	<div class="article-layout-wrapper w-full flex flex-col lg:flex-row gap-5 max-w-full ">
		<article id="post-402749" class="flex-auto post-402749 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-artificial-intelligence category-brain category-health-medicine category-mental-health exclude_tag-yahoo-commerce author_tag-flandymore">
									<section class="entry-content pw-content-edge-targeting" data-module="TableOfContents">
	<div>
			<figure class="article-featured-image-figure">
			<div class="relative ">
	<img
		class="archive-post-thumb article-featured-image w-full h-auto mb-3"

					src="https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/ai-dunning-kruger-effect.jpg?quality=85&w=1152"
		
					srcset="https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/ai-dunning-kruger-effect.jpg?w=280&h=187 280w, https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/ai-dunning-kruger-effect.jpg?w=289&h=193 289w, https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/ai-dunning-kruger-effect.jpg?w=300&h=200 300w, https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/ai-dunning-kruger-effect.jpg?w=308&h=205 308w, https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/ai-dunning-kruger-effect.jpg?w=324&h=216 324w, https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/ai-dunning-kruger-effect.jpg?w=370&h=247 370w, https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/ai-dunning-kruger-effect.jpg?w=580&h=387 580w, https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/ai-dunning-kruger-effect.jpg?w=594&h=396 594w, https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/ai-dunning-kruger-effect.jpg?w=600&h=400 600w, https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/ai-dunning-kruger-effect.jpg?w=660&h=440 660w, https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/ai-dunning-kruger-effect.jpg?w=768&h=512 768w, https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/ai-dunning-kruger-effect.jpg?w=1024&h=683 1024w, https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/ai-dunning-kruger-effect.jpg?w=1041&h=694 1041w, https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/ai-dunning-kruger-effect.jpg?w=1128&h=752 1128w, https://futurism.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/ai-dunning-kruger-effect.jpg?w=1152&h=768 1152w"
		
					sizes="(max-width: 1152px) 100vw, 1152px"
		
		
					fetchpriority="high"
		
					width="2048"
		
					height="1365"
		
		alt="New research shows how AI tools is making a Dunning-Kruger specimen out of everyone that uses them, no matter how smart."
	/>

	</div>
			
	<div class="article-featured-image-caption-container">
		<figcaption class="article-featured-image-caption">
			Illustration by Tag Hartman-Simkins / Futurism. Source: Getty Images
 		</figcaption>
	</div>
		</figure>
	
	
	
	
	
	<div class="content-wrapper" data-toc-container>
		
<p class="pw-incontent-excluded article-paragraph skip">People who are the worst at doing something also tend to severely overestimate how good they are at doing it, while those who are actually skilled tend to not realize their true talent.</p>



<p class="article-paragraph skip">This galling cognitive bias is called the Dunning-Kruger effect, as you’re probably familiar — and would you believe it if we told you that AI appears to make it even worse? </p>



<p class="article-paragraph skip">Case in point, a <a href="https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0747563225002262?via%3Dihub" rel="nofollow noreferrer" target="_blank">new study</a> published in the journal <em>Computers in Human Behavior </em>— and titled, memorably, “AI Makes You smarter But None the Wiser”) — showed that <em>everyone </em>was bad at estimating their own performance after being asked to complete a series of tasks using ChatGPT. And strikingly, it was the participants who were “AI literate” who were the worst offenders.</p>



<p class="article-paragraph skip">“When it comes to AI, the [Dunning-Kruger effect] vanishes,” study senior author Robin Welsch, a professor at Aalto University, said in a <a href="https://www.eurekalert.org/news-releases/1103616" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">statement</a> about the work. “In fact, what’s really surprising is that higher AI literacy brings more overconfidence.”</p>



<p class="article-paragraph skip">“We would expect people who are AI literate to not only be a bit better at interacting with AI systems, but also at judging their performance with those systems,” Welsch added, “but this was not the case.”</p>



<p class="article-paragraph skip">It’s an interesting detail that helps build on our still burgeoning understanding of all the ways that our AI habits are probably bad for our brains, from being linked with <a href="https://futurism.com/the-byte/chatgpt-memory-loss-procrastination">memory loss</a> to <a href="https://futurism.com/study-ai-critical-thinking">atrophying our critical thinking skills</a>. Perhaps it’s also a testament to the ego of the AI power user.</p>



<p class="article-paragraph skip">Notably, the findings comes amid heated debate around the dangerous “<a href="https://futurism.com/sycophancy-chatbots-ai-problem">sycophancy</a>” of AI models. Chatbots designed to both be helpful and engaging constantly ply users with flattery and go along with their demands. It’s an addictive combination that makes you feel smart or vindicated. And this sycophancy is thought to be one of the main driving factors behind <a href="https://futurism.com/future-society/openai-data-chatgpt-mental-health-crises">widespread cases</a> of what <a href="https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/urban-survival/202507/the-emerging-problem-of-ai-psychosis" rel="nofollow noreferrer" target="_blank">psychiatrists are calling</a> “AI psychosis,” in which users suffer breaks with reality and spirals into delusional thinking after becoming obsessed with talking with a chatbot.</p>



<p class="article-paragraph skip">In the study, the researchers asked half of 500 participants to use ChatGPT to help solve 20 logical reasoning problems from the Law School Admission Test, and the other half to solve them without AI. Afterwards, each participant was asked to evaluate their own performance, with the promise of extra compensation if they did so accurately. They were also administered a <a href="https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2451958823000714" rel="nofollow noreferrer" target="_blank">questionnaire designed</a><strong> </strong>to gauge their AI literacy.</p>



<p class="article-paragraph skip">The researchers found that the group that used ChatGPT substantially improved their scores compared to the group that didn’t. But they also vastly overestimated their performance — and the effect was especially pronounced among the AI savvy, “suggesting that those with more technical knowledge of AI were more confident but less precise in judging their own performance,” the authors wrote.</p>



<p class="article-paragraph skip">When they examined how the participants used the chatbot, the team also discovered that the majority of them rarely asked ChatGPT more than one question per problem — with no further probing or double checking. According to Welsch, this is an example of what psychiatrists call cognitive offloading, a well documented trend in AI in which users outsource all their thinking to an AI tool.</p>



<p class="article-paragraph skip">“We looked at whether they truly reflected with the AI system and found that people just thought the AI would solve things for them,” Welsch said. “Usually there was just one single interaction to get the results, which means that users blindly trusted the system.”</p>



<p class="article-paragraph skip">You’ve got to hand it to AI: it’s democratizing the Dunning-Kruger effect. What other tech can claim to do that?</p>



<p class="article-paragraph skip"><strong>More on AI:</strong> <a href="https://futurism.com/artificial-intelligence/character-ai-ban-minors"><em>Character.AI, Accused of Driving Teens to Suicide, Says It Will Ban Minors From Using Its Chatbots</em></a></p>
	</div>

readabilityObject.title: AI Is Causing a Grim New Twist on the Dunning-Kruger Effect, Research Finds
readabilityObject.content:
People who are the worst at doing something also tend to severely overestimate how good they are at doing it, while those who are actually skilled tend to not realize their true talent.

This galling cognitive bias is called the Dunning-Kruger effect, as you’re probably familiar — and would you believe it if we told you that AI appears to make it even worse? 

Case in point, a new study published in the journal Computers in Human Behavior — and titled, memorably, “AI Makes You smarter But None the Wiser”) — showed that everyone was bad at estimating their own performance after being asked to complete a series of tasks using ChatGPT. And strikingly, it was the participants who were “AI literate” who were the worst offenders.

“When it comes to AI, the [Dunning-Kruger effect] vanishes,” study senior author Robin Welsch, a professor at Aalto University, said in a statement about the work. “In fact, what’s really surprising is that higher AI literacy brings more overconfidence.”

“We would expect people who are AI literate to not only be a bit better at interacting with AI systems, but also at judging their performance with those systems,” Welsch added, “but this was not the case.”

It’s an interesting detail that helps build on our still burgeoning understanding of all the ways that our AI habits are probably bad for our brains, from being linked with memory loss to atrophying our critical thinking skills. Perhaps it’s also a testament to the ego of the AI power user.

Notably, the findings comes amid heated debate around the dangerous “sycophancy” of AI models. Chatbots designed to both be helpful and engaging constantly ply users with flattery and go along with their demands. It’s an addictive combination that makes you feel smart or vindicated. And this sycophancy is thought to be one of the main driving factors behind widespread cases of what psychiatrists are calling “AI psychosis,” in which users suffer breaks with reality and spirals into delusional thinking after becoming obsessed with talking with a chatbot.

In the study, the researchers asked half of 500 participants to use ChatGPT to help solve 20 logical reasoning problems from the Law School Admission Test, and the other half to solve them without AI. Afterwards, each participant was asked to evaluate their own performance, with the promise of extra compensation if they did so accurately. They were also administered a questionnaire designed to gauge their AI literacy.

The researchers found that the group that used ChatGPT substantially improved their scores compared to the group that didn’t. But they also vastly overestimated their performance — and the effect was especially pronounced among the AI savvy, “suggesting that those with more technical knowledge of AI were more confident but less precise in judging their own performance,” the authors wrote.

When they examined how the participants used the chatbot, the team also discovered that the majority of them rarely asked ChatGPT more than one question per problem — with no further probing or double checking. According to Welsch, this is an example of what psychiatrists call cognitive offloading, a well documented trend in AI in which users outsource all their thinking to an AI tool.

“We looked at whether they truly reflected with the AI system and found that people just thought the AI would solve things for them,” Welsch said. “Usually there was just one single interaction to get the results, which means that users blindly trusted the system.”

You’ve got to hand it to AI: it’s democratizing the Dunning-Kruger effect. What other tech can claim to do that?

More on AI: Character.AI, Accused of Driving Teens to Suicide, Says It Will Ban Minors From Using Its Chatbots

author.name: Frank Landymore
author.description:
At Futurism, my work has often centered on bringing a sense of clarity and insight to complex topics ranging from the regulation of emerging technologies to the esoteric ideologies of Silicon Valley executives, while striving not to lose the poetic sense of awe inspired by often-obscure fields like astrophysics and quantum computing. 

I broke the story of CNET using AI to produce articles that turned out to be riddled with factual errors and plagiarism — a dam-breaking inflection point, as I've reported, that's inspired copycats and endless discourse while beguiling stakeholders ranging from tech giants to purveyors of spam around the web. My work at Futurism has been cited by publications including CBS News, the Los Angeles Times, Vice, Gizmodo, Engadget, the Verge, and Vanity Fair. 

I grew up in locales ranging from India to China, and now live in the exotic suburbs of Virginia. In my free time, I'm an avid reader of weird sci-fi literature, an aficionado of East Asian cinema, and, regrettably, a relapsed gamer. Allegedly, I’m working on a debut novel, currently untitled.
